text: This is a download from BBC Learning English.

6-Mate English.
From BBC Learning English.
Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English,
the show that brings you an interesting topic,
authentic listening practice and vocabulary
to help you improve your language skills.
I'm Dan.
And I'm Catherine.
In this program, we'll be discussing life expectancy
as well as teaching you six new items of vocabulary, of course.
Err...
Dan?
Dan!
Dan? Dan! We're doing a show, Dan. Wake up!
speaker: Catherine

text: Sorry, Catherine. Sorry, everybody.
Sorry. Sorry, Catherine. Sorry, everybody. I was at a party last night and I didn't get much sleep.
speaker: Dan

text: Another party, Dan?
speaker: Catherine

text: Yeah.
speaker: Dan

text: That's the third this week.
Do you look dead on your feet?
Which is an expression, meaning extremely tired.
Ah, well.
Live fast, die young.
That's my motto.
A motto is a short phrase which reflects
the beliefs of an organisation or person.
And it's interesting that you mentioned dying young Dan
because our topic this show is life expectancy.
Life expectancy is how many years a person is likely to live. I suppose you have a question about it too?
speaker: Life expectancy

text: I suppose you have a question about it too.
Funny you should say that, Dan.
Yeah.
By the year 2030,
will the USA's life expectancy be A in the top third,
B, the middle third,
or C, the bottom third compared to the rest of the world?
Well, the USA is quite a rich country,
The USA is quite a rich country, so I'm going to say a) the top one third.
speaker: Dan

text: And we'll find out later in the show if you're right or not.
Now, Dan, life expectancy.
So which country do you think has the current highest life expectancy?
Everybody knows that's Japan, come on!
speaker: Dan

text: Ah, yes, but new analysis by the World Health Organization
and Imperial College London predicts that it won't always be so.
Now, they analysed 35 industrialised countries
and found that by the year 2030,
South Korea will be the leaders
with an average life expectancy of a whopping 90 years.
Wow.
Wow. How did they do that?
speaker: Dan

text: Well, let's find out by listening to Professor Majid Azati,
Well, let's find out by listening to Professor Majid Ezzati, Chair in Global Environmental Health at Imperial College London.
speaker: Catherine

text: It seems to be actually dealing with diet,
but other places,
being very good at taking up new medical knowledge,
technology and using it,
and perhaps most importantly doing this in a relatively equitable way
compared to Western countries.
So basically, good diet,
using new medical technology and knowledge
and being more equitable or fair and impartial in society.
So how did the UK do?
Well, not too well, actually.
Well, not too well actually. We were thoroughly beaten by our closest neighbour, France.
speaker: Catherine

text: What!? How comes!?
speaker: Dan

text: I'll let Professor Majid Azati explain that too.
So France has had some of the lowest obesity rates
in the Western countries,
French women especially.
UK has had some of the highest ones.
And alcohol in France,
at least until now, has been consumed
in much more healthy patterns.
And in the UK, there has been a lot more binge drinking.
So France has low obesity,
which is a state of being very overweight
compared to the UK's high obesity.
And France drinks alcohol much more moderately than the UK, which tends to binge.
speaker: binge

text: than the UK, which tends to binge.
Binging is when you consume a large amount of something
in a short time, especially food or alcohol.
So confession time, Dan.
How many drinks did you have last night?
It was only orange juice, I swear.
So come on, did I get the question right?
You asked me by the year 2030,
will the USA's life expectancy be A in the top one third,
B the middle one third,
or C the bottom one third compared to the rest of the world?
And I said the USA is quite a rich country,
so it's probably A in the top one third.
Sorry, Dan. Nice logic,
but actually the USA is one of the least equitable places in the world.
So their life expectancy suffers,
and the answer was actually C the bottom third.
Oh, well, next week maybe.
Now, let's take a look at the vocabulary from this program.
First, we had dead on your feet.
This is an informal expression,
which means extremely tired.
Another way to say the same thing would be shattered.
When was the last time you were dead on your feet, Catherine?
I built some garden furniture quite recently,
and it took me all day, and I was dead on my feet when I finished.
Now, we had motto.
Now a motto is a short phrase,
which reflects the belief of an organisation or person.
So, Dan, what's your personal motto?
'Take the path of least resistance'. What about you?
speaker: Dan

text: What about you?
'Less is more'.
speaker: Catherine

text: Yeah, good one.
Then we had life expectancy.
Life expectancy is how many years a person is likely to live.
What do you think is a good life expectancy for a person?
I'm hoping to get to about 85,
and then I'd like a sort of quick access,
because I think it's probably not much fun after that.
Then we had equitable.
Equitable means being fair or impartial,
and it comes from the word equal.
So, Dan, personal question,
would you say that your marriage is equitable?
I'd like to think so, yes.
I do the cooking.
My wife does the cleaning,
and we share the other jobs.
We'll have to get Mrs. Dan in to give her opinion.
speaker: Catherine

text: After that, we heard obesity.
Obesity describes a state of being very overweight.
It's a medical term,
and is often used in connection with health problems.
The report said that the UK has an obesity problem, Catherine.
How do you think we can solve it?
I think we need a sugar tax,
and everybody should walk to work.
Finally, we had binge.
To binge is to consume a large amount of something
in a short space of time.
Especially something that you don't usually have.
And these days, we hear a lot about binge drinking, binge eating,
and binge watching.
So, Dan, when did you last binge watch a series on TV?
It's Game of Thrones.
Game of Thrones?
Game of Series 1, Series 2, Series 3.
Back to back.
Back to back, bingeing, brilliant.
Well, that's the end of today's six-minute English.
Please join us again soon.
And we're on social media too,
so make sure you find us on Twitter,
Facebook, Instagram, and YouTube.
Bye!
